p: If a perfect crystal is bent with negative strain gradient (β < 0), the trajectory of the refracted beam shows a hyperbolic form opening down and the beam always reaches the back surface as shown in Fig. 2 ▸( a). Fig. 2 ▸( c) shows that the tie points corresponding to the refracted beam S′ 1 and S′ 2 move on the dispersion surface in the range indicated by red lines. IFRB can be observed between two beams, i.e. one ( S′ 2) reflected once from the back surface and the other ( S′′ 4) reflected twice from the back surface in Fig. 2 ▸( b). γ is the angle of the refracted beam from the surface at the incident point. Similar interference fringes can be observed between two beams n and n + 1 ( n is a positive integer) times reflected from the back surface. IFTB also can be observed for β < 0.
